newsitem.title: UK: Traders mixed on Urals despite heavy Dec programme.
newsitem.headline: Traders mixed on Urals despite heavy Dec programme.

text.p: Mediterranean oil traders had mixed views on the value of Urals on Thursday following the release of the December loading programme.

The programme schedules the loading of a heavy 2,767,000 tonnes of crude for December despite the planned closure of berth number one from Dec 9-24, and the three- to four-day closure of the main pipeline feeding Novorossiisk planned for some point during the month.
Berth one is the only berth at Novorossiisk that can accommodate tankers of 100,000-140,000 tonnes.
The programme plans a brisk loading schedule of 60,000-80,000 tonne tankers from berths six and seven.
"The programme is for huge quantities," said one Med refiner. "Even if only 70 percent of the programme gets out, Urals is going to weaken to around (Dated Brent) -40/50 (cents)."

The refiner said that sweet West African grades offered a margin of 50/60 cents a barrel over Urals. Prices for Iraqi Kirkuk crude, expected back on the market this month, are also more attractive, he said.
But other traders said exports of Urals were likely to be heavily crimped by maintenance and bad winter weather at Novorossiisk.
"You'd have to be from another planet to think that we're going to see plenty of Urals in December," said one trader for a European major.
The trader valued Urals at around Dated Brent -10 cents, with offers still at Dated Brent parity.
West African grades were virtually sold out for December, with just 5-6 million barrels still unsold, traders said.
Two cargoes of Bonny Light, two Forcados and a Brass River were still seen offered. Good buying interest was seen from the U.S. as well as the Med.

A Qua Iboe cargo, already on the water having loaded Dec 2-4, was heard traded at Dated Brent +35 cents. But this was not seen as representative of the market after a third decade Dec cargo traded earlier in the week at Dated +50/55 cents.
